text: Spider-Man: Far From Home has some great action, humor, a great villain, and great performances, especially from Tom Holland and Jake Gyllenhaal, which make it a rewarding, and easy watch Marvel movie.

Spider-Man: Far From Home tries to balance high-school comedy, romance, and post-Endgame heroism, but the story feels uneven and full of questionable choices. Peter Parker’s decision to blow off a global threat just to go on a date with MJ feels wildly out of character and weakens the film’s emotional weight. The writing often relies on convenient plot turns—MJ admitting she was only interested in Peter because she thought he was Spider-Man, or Mysterio trying to kill Peter’s classmates even after his cover is already gone. The humor feels forced and childish, and when the group believes they’re about to die, their sudden confessions don’t feel earned. Mysterio’s drone technology is also under-explained, raising questions about how something so powerful could go unnoticed by world governments or other heroes. By the end, the movie seems to rewrite its own logic just to push the story forward, skipping a proper reveal of Quentin Beck’s backstory as a former Stark employee. While Tom Holland and Zendaya have great chemistry and the European settings are fun, the weak writing and inconsistent tone make Far From Home one of the more disappointing Spider-Man entries—entertaining at moments, but ultimately hollow beneath the spectacle
I wish Stan Lee saw this he would be proud quite literally just a teenage superhero making mistakes.

Critics Consensus:
Stylish and entertaining but a bit uneven, Spider-Man: Far From Home delivers plenty of laughs and spectacle, even if it sometimes gets tangled in its own web of world-building. As a post-Endgame epilogue, it’s fun and fast-paced—but lacks some of the emotional depth and focus that made Homecoming so refreshing.

Tom Holland continues to shine as Peter Parker, effortlessly balancing awkward teen energy with genuine heroism. Jake Gyllenhaal’s Mysterio is charismatic and visually stunning, though his arc ultimately leans more on CGI than character. The film’s globe-trotting adventure offers some thrilling set pieces, but the constant shifts in tone—from high-school comedy to high-stakes superhero drama—can make it feel a little disjointed.

Despite its flaws, Far From Home remains an enjoyable, good-hearted entry in the Spider-Man saga. It’s not the tightest or most resonant web the MCU has spun, but it’s still a fun ride that keeps the friendly neighborhood hero flying high.

I’m not exactly sure what I am doing with these reviews for the post-Endgame Marvel movies.  I’m not a Marvel fan boy but I have seen some of them and did parachute in for the finale films, around the time I decided I was mostly done with superhero movies in the theater.  Up until now, I hadn’t seen any of the post-Endgame Marvel movies, other than Spider-Man: No Way Home but my Disney+ account was collecting dust so I queded up all the Marvel films since Endgame and finally found some time to view them. I’m not sure of these reviews because my first time viewing them is as one and in the order of release after a re-viewing of the Infinite/Endgame saga, but here goes.... 

while not the biggest fan of this version of Spider-Man films, I felt this was a good follow-up to Endgame. The villain was a bit questionable and there was a bit too much Degrassi feel to it with more focus on the high school aged students than previous Spider-man films.  This basically felt like a filler episode, but a necessary one because there was no going bigger and outshining Endgame.  This was competently made and did what it needed to do, but it’s definitely not going to endear itself upon the hearts of humanity.. or even casual Marvel fans.
	
Probably could have been scored higher but I simply did not like it that much and there is a +/- 1/2 star chance of error for all my reviews.
A good movie, not as good as the first but an interesting Spider-Man film that takes place outside of New York. Jake Gyllenhaal as Mysterio is great!
